title: Mondo 2000
contentText: Jude Milhon (aka St Jude) and R. U. Sirius launch Mondo 2000, a major '90s tech-lifestyle magazine, in Berkeley, California.
content: Jude Milhon (aka St Jude) and R. U. Sirius launch Mondo 2000, a major '90s tech-lifestyle magazine, in Berkeley, California.

title: The first ransomware
contentText: The detection of AIDS (Trojan horse) is the first instance of a ransomware detection.
content: The detection of AIDS (Trojan horse) is the first instance of a ransomware detection.

title: Operation Sundevil
contentText: Operation Sundevil introduced.  After a prolonged sting investigation, Secret Service agents swoop down on organizers and prominent members of BBSs in 14 U.S. cities including the Legion of Doom, conducting early-morning raids and arrests. The arrests involve and are aimed at cracking down on credit-card theft and telephone and wire fraud. The result is a breakdown in the hacking community, with members informing on each other in exchange for immunity. The offices of Steve Jackson Games are also raided, and the role-playing sourcebook GURPS Cyberpunk is confiscated, possibly because the government fears it is a "handbook for computer crime". Legal battles arise that prompt the formation of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, including the trial of Knight Lightning.
content: Operation Sundevil introduced. After a prolonged sting investigation, Secret Service agents swoop down on organizers and prominent members of BBSs in 14 U.S. cities including the Legion of Doom, conducting early-morning raids and arrests. The arrests involve and are aimed at cracking down on credit-card theft and telephone and wire fraud. The result is a breakdown in the hacking community, with members informing on each other in exchange for immunity. The offices of Steve Jackson Games are also raided, and the role-playing sourcebook GURPS Cyberpunk is confiscated, possibly because the government fears it is a "handbook for computer crime". Legal battles arise that prompt the formation of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, including the trial of Knight Lightning.

title: Computer Misuse Act
contentText: The Computer Misuse Act 1990 is passed in the United Kingdom, criminalising any unauthorised access to computer systems.
content: The Computer Misuse Act 1990 is passed in the United Kingdom, criminalising any unauthorised access to computer systems.

title: Sneakers
contentText: Release of the movie Sneakers, in which security experts are blackmailed into stealing a universal decoder for encryption systems.
content: Release of the movie Sneakers, in which security experts are blackmailed into stealing a universal decoder for encryption systems.

title: First polymorphic code
contentText: Bulgarian virus writer Dark Avenger wrote 1260, the first known use of polymorphic code, used to circumvent the type of pattern recognition used by antivirus software, and nowadays also intrusion detection systems.
content: Bulgarian virus writer Dark Avenger wrote 1260, the first known use of polymorphic code, used to circumvent the type of pattern recognition used by antivirus software, and nowadays also intrusion detection systems.

title: DEF CON
contentText: The first DEF CON hacking conference takes place in Las Vegas. The conference is meant to be a one-time party to say good-bye to BBSs (now replaced by the Web), but the gathering was so popular it became an annual event.
content: The first DEF CON hacking conference takes place in Las Vegas. The conference is meant to be a one-time party to say good-bye to BBSs (now replaced by the Web), but the gathering was so popular it became an annual event.

title: Citibank
contentText: Summer: Russian crackers siphon $10 million from Citibank and transfer the money to bank accounts around the world. Vladimir Levin, the 30-year-old ringleader, uses his work laptop after hours to transfer the funds to accounts in Finland and Israel. Levin stands trial in the United States and is sentenced to three years in prison. Authorities recover all but $400,000 of the stolen money.
content: Summer: Russian crackers siphon $10 million from Citibank and transfer the money to bank accounts around the world. Vladimir Levin, the 30-year-old ringleader, uses his work laptop after hours to transfer the funds to accounts in Finland and Israel. Levin stands trial in the United States and is sentenced to three years in prison. Authorities recover all but $400,000 of the stolen money.

title: Hackers go on the WWW
contentText: Hackers adapt to emergence of the World Wide Web quickly, moving all their how-to information and hacking programs from the old BBSs to new hacker web sites.
content: Hackers adapt to emergence of the World Wide Web quickly, moving all their how-to information and hacking programs from the old BBSs to new hacker web sites.

title: AOHell
contentText: AOHell is released, a freeware application that allows a burgeoning community of unskilled script kiddies to wreak havoc on America Online. For days, hundreds of thousands of AOL users find their mailboxes flooded with multi-megabyte email bombs and their chat rooms disrupted with spam messages.
content: AOHell is released, a freeware application that allows a burgeoning community of unskilled script kiddies to wreak havoc on America Online. For days, hundreds of thousands of AOL users find their mailboxes flooded with multi-megabyte email bombs and their chat rooms disrupted with spam messages.

title: The Net + Hackers
contentText: The movies The Net and Hackers are released.
content: The movies The Net and Hackers are released.

title: FBI raids Phone Masters
contentText: February 22: The FBI raids the "Phone Masters".
content: February 22: The FBI raids the "Phone Masters".

title: CIA website
contentText: Hackers alter Web sites of the United States Department of Justice (August), the CIA (October), and the U.S. Air Force (December).
content: Hackers alter Web sites of the United States Department of Justice (August), the CIA (October), and the U.S. Air Force (December).

title: 250000 attempts
contentText: The U.S. General Accounting Office reports that hackers attempted to break into Defense Department computer files some 250,000 times in 1995 alone. About 65 percent of the attempts were successful, according to the report.
content: The U.S. General Accounting Office reports that hackers attempted to break into Defense Department computer files some 250,000 times in 1995 alone. About 65 percent of the attempts were successful, according to the report.

title: The rise of MP3 sharing
contentText: The MP3 format gains popularity in the hacker world. Many hackers begin setting up sharing sites via FTP, Hotline, IRC and Usenet.
content: The MP3 format gains popularity in the hacker world. Many hackers begin setting up sharing sites via FTP, Hotline, IRC and Usenet.

title: Cryptovirology
contentText: Cryptovirology is born with the invention of the cryptoviral extortion protocol that would later form the basis of modern ransomware.
content: Cryptovirology is born with the invention of the cryptoviral extortion protocol that would later form the basis of modern ransomware.

title: US Air Force pwned
contentText: A 15-year-old Croatian youth penetrates computers at a U.S. Air Force base in Guam.
content: A 15-year-old Croatian youth penetrates computers at a U.S. Air Force base in Guam.

title: Recording Industry Association
contentText: In response to the popularity of sharing MP3 music files online, the Recording Industry Association of America begins cracking down on file sharing.
content: In response to the popularity of sharing MP3 music files online, the Recording Industry Association of America begins cracking down on file sharing.

title: Information Security
contentText: December: Information Security publishes first issue.
content: December: Information Security publishes first issue.

title: A logic bomb from Yahoo!
contentText: January: Yahoo! notifies Internet users that anyone visiting its site in the past month might have downloaded a logic bomb and worm planted by hackers claiming a "logic bomb" will go off if computer hacker Kevin Mitnick is not released from prison.
content: January: Yahoo! notifies Internet users that anyone visiting its site in the past month might have downloaded a logic bomb and worm planted by hackers claiming a "logic bomb" will go off if computer hacker Kevin Mitnick is not released from prison.

title: 3/4 of organizations hacked
contentText: June: Information Security publishes its first annual Industry Survey, finding that nearly three-quarters of organizations suffered a security incident in the previous year.
content: June: Information Security publishes its first annual Industry Survey, finding that nearly three-quarters of organizations suffered a security incident in the previous year.

title: Art or hack?
contentText: September: Electronic Disturbance Theater, an online political performance-art group,  attacks the websites of The Pentagon, Mexican president Ernesto Zedillo, and the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, calling it conceptual art and claiming it to be a protest against the suppression of the Zapatista Army of National Liberation in southern Mexico. EDT uses the FloodNet software to bombard its opponents with access requests.
content: September: Electronic Disturbance Theater, an online political performance-art group, attacks the websites of The Pentagon, Mexican president Ernesto Zedillo, and the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, calling it conceptual art and claiming it to be a protest against the suppression of the Zapatista Army of National Liberation in southern Mexico. EDT uses the FloodNet software to bombard its opponents with access requests.

title: Security goes mainstream
contentText: Software security goes mainstream In the wake of Microsoft's Windows 98 release, 1999 becomes a banner year for security (and hacking). Hundreds of advisories and patches are released in response to newfound (and widely publicized) bugs in Windows and other commercial software products. A host of security software vendors release anti-hacking products for use on home computers.
content: Software security goes mainstream In the wake of Microsoft's Windows 98 release, 1999 becomes a banner year for security (and hacking). Hundreds of advisories and patches are released in response to newfound (and widely publicized) bugs in Windows and other commercial software products. A host of security software vendors release anti-hacking products for use on home computers.

title: $1.46 billion initiative
contentText: U.S. President Bill Clinton announces a $1.46 billion initiative to improve government computer security. The plan would establish a network of intrusion detection monitors for certain federal agencies and encourage the private sector to do the same.
content: U.S. President Bill Clinton announces a $1.46 billion initiative to improve government computer security. The plan would establish a network of intrusion detection monitors for certain federal agencies and encourage the private sector to do the same.

title: Legion of the Underground
contentText: January 7: The "Legion of the Underground" (LoU) declares "war" against the governments of Iraq and the People's Republic of China. An international coalition of hackers (including Cult of the Dead Cow, 2600's staff, Phrack's staff, L0pht, and the Chaos Computer Club) issued a joint statement ([4]) condemning the LoU's declaration of war.  The LoU responded by withdrawing its declaration.
content: January 7: The "Legion of the Underground" (LoU) declares "war" against the governments of Iraq and the People's Republic of China. An international coalition of hackers (including Cult of the Dead Cow, 2600's staff, Phrack's staff, L0pht, and the Chaos Computer Club) issued a joint statement ([4]) condemning the LoU's declaration of war. The LoU responded by withdrawing its declaration.

title: The Melissa worm
contentText: March: The Melissa worm is released and quickly becomes the most costly malware outbreak to date.
content: March: The Melissa worm is released and quickly becomes the most costly malware outbreak to date.

title: Derailing trains
contentText: November 17: A hacker interviewed by Hilly Rose during the radio show Coast to Coast AM (then hosted by Art Bell) exposes a plot by al-Qaeda to derail Amtrak trains. This results in all trains being forcibly stopped over Y2K as a safety measure.
content: November 17: A hacker interviewed by Hilly Rose during the radio show Coast to Coast AM (then hosted by Art Bell) exposes a plot by al-Qaeda to derail Amtrak trains. This results in all trains being forcibly stopped over Y2K as a safety measure.

title: ILOVEYOU
contentText: May: The ILOVEYOU worm, also known as VBS/Loveletter and Love Bug worm, is a computer worm written in VBScript.  It infected millions of computers worldwide within a few hours of its release.  It is considered to be one of the most damaging worms ever. It originated in the Philippines; made by an AMA Computer College student for his thesis. 10% of computers connected to the internet were infected.
content: May: The ILOVEYOU worm, also known as VBS/Loveletter and Love Bug worm, is a computer worm written in VBScript. It infected millions of computers worldwide within a few hours of its release. It is considered to be one of the most damaging worms ever. It originated in the Philippines; made by an AMA Computer College student for his thesis.

title: The first in jail
contentText: September: Computer hacker Jonathan James became the first juvenile to serve jail time for hacking.
content: September: Computer hacker Jonathan James became the first juvenile to serve jail time for hacking.

title: First DoS attacks
contentText: Microsoft becomes the prominent victim of a new type of hack that attacks the domain name server. In these denial-of-service attacks, the DNS paths that take users to Microsoft's websites are corrupted.
content: Microsoft becomes the prominent victim of a new type of hack that attacks the domain name server. In these denial-of-service attacks, the DNS paths that take users to Microsoft's websites are corrupted.

title: National Cyber Security Alliance
contentText: The National Cyber Security Alliance (NCSA) is established in response to the September 11 attacks on the World Trade Center.
content: The National Cyber Security Alliance (NCSA) is established in response to the September 11 attacks on the World Trade Center.

title: Tricky FBI
contentText: April: FBI agents trick two Russian crackers into coming to the U.S. and revealing how they were hacking U.S. banks.
content: April: FBI agents trick two Russian crackers into coming to the U.S. and revealing how they were hacking U.S. banks.

title: First DMCA incrimination
contentText: July: Russian programmer Dmitry Sklyarov is arrested at the annual Def Con hacker convention. He was the first person criminally charged with violating the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA).
content: July: Russian programmer Dmitry Sklyarov is arrested at the annual Def Con hacker convention. He was the first person criminally charged with violating the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA).

title: Code Red worm
contentText: August: Code Red worm, infects tens of thousands of machines.
content: August: Code Red worm, infects tens of thousands of machines.

title: Anonymous
contentText: The hacktivist group Anonymous was formed.
content: The hacktivist group Anonymous was formed.

title: North Korean hackers
contentText: July: North Korea claims to have trained 500 hackers who successfully crack South Korean, Japanese, and their allies' computer systems.
content: July: North Korea claims to have trained 500 hackers who successfully crack South Korean, Japanese, and their allies' computer systems.

title: CardSystems Solutions Inc.(MasterCard, Visa, Discover Financial Services and American Express)
contentText: CardSystems Solutions Inc.(MasterCard, Visa, Discover Financial Services and American Express) was hacked.
content: CardSystems Solutions Inc.(MasterCard, Visa, Discover Financial Services and American Express) was hacked.

title: Citigroup
contentText:
In one of the largest breaches of data security to date, CitiFinancial, the consumer finance subsidiary of Citigroup, announced yesterday that a box of computer tapes containing information on 3.9 million customers was lost by United Parcel Service last month, while in transit to a credit reporting agency. [...] 

The tapes contained names, addresses, Social Security numbers, account numbers, payment histories and other details on small personal loans [...].
content:
In one of the largest breaches of data security to date, CitiFinancial, the consumer finance subsidiary of Citigroup, announced yesterday that a box of computer tapes containing information on 3.9 million customers was lost by United Parcel Service last month, while in transit to a credit reporting agency. [...] 

The tapes contained names, addresses, Social Security numbers, account numbers, payment histories and other details on small personal loans [...].

title: Bank of America
contentText:
Bank of America Corp. has lost computer data tapes containing personal information on up to 1.2 million federal employees, including some members of the U.S. Senate.

The lost data includes Social Security numbers and account information that could make customers of a federal government charge card program vulnerable to identity theft.
content:
Bank of America Corp. has lost computer data tapes containing personal information on up to 1.2 million federal employees, including some members of the U.S. Senate.

The lost data includes Social Security numbers and account information that could make customers of a federal government charge card program vulnerable to identity theft.

title: AOL Proudly Releases Massive Amounts of Private Data
contentText: AOL records were accidentally published. The data includes all searches from those users for a three month period this year, as well as whether they clicked on a result, what that result was and where it appeared on the result page. It’s a 439 MB compressed download, expanded to just over 2 gigs.
content: AOL records were accidentally published. The data includes all searches from those users for a three month period this year, as well as whether they clicked on a result, what that result was and where it appeared on the result page. It’s a 439 MB compressed download, expanded to just over 2 gigs.

title: The largest defacement in Web History
contentText: May: The largest defacement in Web History as of that time is performed by the Turkish hacker iSKORPiTX who successfully hacked 21,549 websites in one shot.
content: May: The largest defacement in Web History as of that time is performed by the Turkish hacker iSKORPiTX who successfully hacked 21,549 websites in one shot.

title: Monster.com
contentText:
US job website Monster.com has suffered an online attack with the personal data of hundreds of thousands of users stolen, says a security firm.

This remote server held over 1.6 million entries with personal information belonging to several hundred thousands of candidates, mainly based in the US, who had posted their resumes to the Monster.com website," reported Symantec.
content:
US job website Monster.com has suffered an online attack with the personal data of hundreds of thousands of users stolen, says a security firm.

This remote server held over 1.6 million entries with personal information belonging to several hundred thousands of candidates, mainly based in the US, who had posted their resumes to the Monster.com website," reported Symantec.

title: UK Revenue & Customs
contentText:
HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) has lost computer disks containing confidential details of 25 million child benefit recipients.
The organisation says it does not believe the records - names, addresses, dates of birth and bank accounts - have fallen into the wrong hands. This is not the first time it has lost sensitive information.
content:
HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) has lost computer disks containing confidential details of 25 million child benefit recipients.
The organisation says it does not believe the records - names, addresses, dates of birth and bank accounts - have fallen into the wrong hands. This is not the first time it has lost sensitive information.

title: Massive DDoS on Estonia
contentText: May 17: Estonia recovers from massive denial-of-service attack
content: May 17: Estonia recovers from massive denial-of-service attack

title: All the credit cards
contentText: Data Processors Internationa (MasterCard, Visa, Discover Financial Services and American Express) was hacked.
content: Data Processors Internationa (MasterCard, Visa, Discover Financial Services and American Express) was hacked.

title: Norwegian Tax Administration
contentText: Norwegian Tax Administration was accidentally published.
content: Norwegian Tax Administration was accidentally published.

title: Stanford University
contentText: A data breach resulting from a stolen laptop has leaked sensitive information including Social Security Numbers of approximately 72,000 former and current Standford University employees.
visualValueSuffix: records were lost because of a lost or stolen computer.
content: A data breach resulting from a stolen laptop has leaked sensitive information including Social Security Numbers of approximately 72,000 former and current Standford University employees.

title: Starbucks
contentText: Starbucks had a lost / stolen computer.
visualValueSuffix: records were lost because of a lost or stolen computer.
content: Starbucks had a lost / stolen computer.

title: UK Ministry of Defence
contentText: UK Ministry of Defence had a data breach.
content: UK Ministry of Defence had a data breach.

title: Chinese hackers vs. The Pentagon
contentText: March 7: Around 20 Chinese hackers claim to have gained access to the world's most sensitive sites, including The Pentagon. They operated from an apartment on a Chinese Island.
content: March 7: Around 20 Chinese hackers claim to have gained access to the world's most sensitive sites, including The Pentagon. They operated from an apartment on a Chinese Island.

title: National Archives and Records Administration (U.S. military veterans' records)
contentText: National Archives and Records Administration (U.S. military veterans' records) had a data breach.
content: National Archives and Records Administration (U.S. military veterans' records) had a data breach.

title: Conficker
contentText: April 4: Conficker worm infiltrated millions of PCs worldwide including many government-level top-security computer networks.
content: April 4: Conficker worm infiltrated millions of PCs worldwide including many government-level top-security computer networks.

title: Gawker
contentText: Gawker was hacked.
content: Gawker was hacked.

title: JP Morgan Chase
contentText: JP Morgan Chase had a data breach.
content: JP Morgan Chase had a data breach.

title: Classified Iraq War documents
contentText: Classified Iraq War documents from the U.S. Army were leaker by an inside job.
visualValueSuffix: records were leaked by an inside job.
content: Classified Iraq War documents from the U.S. Army were leaker by an inside job.

title: U.S. government (United States diplomatic cables leak)
contentText: The United States diplomatic cables leak, widely known as Cablegate, began on Sunday, 28 November 2010 when WikiLeaks—a non-profit organization that publishes submissions from anonymous whistleblowers—began releasing classified cables that had been sent to the U.S. State Department by 274 of its consulates, embassies, and diplomatic missions around the world.
visualValueSuffix: records were leaked by an inside job.
content: The United States diplomatic cables leak, widely known as Cablegate, began on Sunday, 28 November 2010 when WikiLeaks—a non-profit organization that publishes submissions from anonymous whistleblowers—began releasing classified cables that had been sent to the U.S. State Department by 274 of its consulates, embassies, and diplomatic missions around the world.

title: Stuxnet vs. Iran
contentText: June: Stuxnet The Stuxnet worm is found by VirusBlokAda. Stuxnet was unusual in that while it spread via Windows computers, its payload targeted just one specific model and type of SCADA systems. It slowly became clear that it was a cyber attack on Iran's nuclear facilities - with most experts believing that Israel was behind it - perhaps with US help.
content: June: Stuxnet The Stuxnet worm is found by VirusBlokAda. Stuxnet was unusual in that while it spread via Windows computers, its payload targeted just one specific model and type of SCADA systems. It slowly became clear that it was a cyber attack on Iran's nuclear facilities - with most experts believing that Israel was behind it - perhaps with US help.

title: Birth of Lulz Security
contentText: The hacker group Lulz Security is formed.
content: The hacker group Lulz Security is formed.

title: China Software Developer Network
contentText: China Software Developer Network was hacked.
content: China Software Developer Network was hacked.

title: Chinese gaming websites (three: Duowan, 7K7K, 178.com)
contentText: Chinese gaming websites (three: Duowan, 7K7K, 178.com) was hacked.
content: Chinese gaming websites (three: Duowan, 7K7K, 178.com) was hacked.

title: Citigroup
contentText: Citigroup was hacked.
content: Citigroup was hacked.

title: Health Net — IBM
contentText: Health Net — IBM had a data breach.
content: Health Net — IBM had a data breach.

title: Sega
contentText: Sega was hacked.
content: Sega was hacked.

title: Sony
contentText: On November 24, 2014, a hacker group which identified itself by the name "Guardians of Peace" (GOP) leaked a release of confidential data from the film studio Sony Pictures. The data included personal information about Sony Pictures employees and their families, e-mails between employees, information about executive salaries at the company, copies of then-unreleased Sony films, and other information. The perpetrators then employed a variant of the Shamoon wiper malware to erase Sony's computer infrastructure.
content: On November 24, 2014, a hacker group which identified itself by the name "Guardians of Peace" (GOP) leaked a release of confidential data from the film studio Sony Pictures. The data included personal information about Sony Pictures employees and their families, e-mails between employees, information about executive salaries at the company, copies of then-unreleased Sony films, and other information. The perpetrators then employed a variant of the Shamoon wiper malware to erase Sony's computer infrastructure.

title: Steam
contentText: Steam was hacked.
content: Steam was hacked.

title: Washington Post
contentText: Washington Post was hacked.
content: Washington Post was hacked.

title: Stolen credit cards
contentText: April 9: Bank of America website got hacked by a Turkish hacker named JeOPaRDY. An estimated 85,000 credit card numbers and accounts were reported to have been stolen due to the hack. Bank officials say no personal customer bank information is available on that web-page. Investigations are being conducted by the FBI to trace down the incriminated hacker.
content: April 9: Bank of America website got hacked by a Turkish hacker named JeOPaRDY. An estimated 85,000 credit card numbers and accounts were reported to have been stolen due to the hack. Bank officials say no personal customer bank information is available on that web-page. Investigations are being conducted by the FBI to trace down the incriminated hacker.

title: PSNetwork: One of the 5 largest hack
contentText: April 17: An "external intrusion" sends the PlayStation Network offline, and compromises personally identifying information (possibly including credit card details) of its 77 million accounts, in what is claimed to be one of the five largest data breaches ever.
content: April 17: An "external intrusion" sends the PlayStation Network offline, and compromises personally identifying information (possibly including credit card details) of its 77 million accounts, in what is claimed to be one of the five largest data breaches ever.

title: New defacement world record
contentText: September: Bangladeshi hacker TiGER-M@TE made a world record in defacement history by hacking 700,000 websites in a single shot.
content: September: Bangladeshi hacker TiGER-M@TE made a world record in defacement history by hacking 700,000 websites in a single shot.

title: 1'400'000 vs. 200?
contentText: A Saudi hacker, 0XOMAR, published over 400,000 credit cards online, and threatened Israel to release 1 million credit cards in the future. In response to that incident, an Israeli hacker published over 200 Saudi's credit cards online.
content: A Saudi hacker, 0XOMAR, published over 400,000 credit cards online, and threatened Israel to release 1 million credit cards in the future. In response to that incident, an Israeli hacker published over 200 Saudi's credit cards online.

contentText: Apple, Inc./BlueToad was accidentally published.
content: Apple, Inc./BlueToad was accidentally published.

contentText: Blizzard Entertainment was hacked.
content: Blizzard Entertainment was hacked.

contentText: Greek government was hacked.

contentText: Iranian banks (three: Saderat, Eghtesad Novin, and Saman) was hacked.

contentText:
Massive American business were hacked,
including 7-Eleven and Nasdaq.

Massive American business were hacked,
including 7-Eleven and Nasdaq.

contentText: Rambler.ru was hacked.

title: LinkedIn hacked
contentText: June 5: The social networking website LinkedIn has been hacked and the passwords for nearly 6.5 million user accounts are stolen by cybercriminals. As a result, a United States grand jury indicted Nikulin and three unnamed co-conspirators on charges of aggravated identity theft and computer intrusion.
content: June 5: The social networking website LinkedIn has been hacked and the passwords for nearly 6.5 million user accounts are stolen by cybercriminals. As a result, a United States grand jury indicted Nikulin and three unnamed co-conspirators on charges of aggravated identity theft and computer intrusion.

title: Shamoon's retaliation
contentText: August 15: The most valuable company in the world Saudi Aramco is crippled by a cyber warfare attack for months by malware called Shamoon. Considered the biggest hack in history in terms of cost and destructiveness . Carried out by an Iranian attacker group called Cutting Sword of Justice. Iranian hackers retaliated against Stuxnet by releasing Shamoon. The malware destroyed over 35,000 Saudi Aramco computers, affecting business operations for months.
content: August 15: The most valuable company in the world Saudi Aramco is crippled by a cyber warfare attack for months by malware called Shamoon. Considered the biggest hack in history in terms of cost and destructiveness . Carried out by an Iranian attacker group called Cutting Sword of Justice. Iranian hackers retaliated against Stuxnet by releasing Shamoon. The malware destroyed over 35,000 Saudi Aramco computers, affecting business operations for months.

title: A whole bunch of Tumblr accounts
contentText: The social networking website Tumblr is attacked by hackers. Consequently, 65,469,298 unique emails and passwords were leaked from Tumblr. The data breach's legitimacy is confirmed by computer security researcher Troy Hunt.

title: Mt.Gox
contentText: February 7: The bitcoin exchange Mt.Gox filed for bankruptcy after $460 million was apparently stolen by hackers due to "weaknesses in [their] system" and another $27.4 million went missing from its bank accounts.

title: 21 millions fingerprints
contentText: June:  the records of 21.5 million people, including social security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, fingerprints, and security-clearance-related information, are stolen from the United States Office of Personnel Management.  Most of the victims are employees of the United States government and unsuccessful applicants to it. The Wall Street Journal and the Washington Post report that government sources believe the hacker is the government of China.
content: June: the records of 21.5 million people, including social security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, fingerprints, and security-clearance-related information, are stolen from the United States Office of Personnel Management. Most of the victims are employees of the United States government and unsuccessful applicants to it. The Wall Street Journal and the Washington Post report that government sources believe the hacker is the government of China.

title: Bangladesh Bank

title: Equifax
contentText: On September 7, 2017, Equifax announced a cybercrime identity theft event potentially impacting approximately 145.5 million U.S. consumers. Information on an estimated range of under 400,000 up to 44 million British residents as well as 8,000 Canadian residents were also compromised. An additional 11,670 Canadians were affected as well, later revealed by Equifax. VentureBeat called the exposure of data on 140+ million customers "one of the biggest data breaches in history."
visualValueSuffix: records were lost due to poor security.
content: On September 7, 2017, Equifax announced a cybercrime identity theft event potentially impacting approximately 145.5 million U.S. consumers. Information on an estimated range of under 400,000 up to 44 million British residents as well as 8,000 Canadian residents were also compromised. An additional 11,670 Canadians were affected as well, later revealed by Equifax. VentureBeat called the exposure of data on 140+ million customers "one of the biggest data breaches in history."

title: WannaCry
contentText: May: WannaCry ransomware attack started on Friday, 12 May 2017, and has been described as unprecedented in scale, infecting more than 230,000 computers in over 150 countries.
content: May: WannaCry ransomware attack started on Friday, 12 May 2017, and has been described as unprecedented in scale, infecting more than 230,000 computers in over 150 countries.

title: Petya
contentText: A series of powerful cyberattacks using the Petya malware began on 27 June 2017 that swamped websites of Ukrainian organizations, including banks, ministries, newspapers and electricity firms. Similar infections were reported in France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Russia, United Kingdom, the United States and Australia. ESET estimated on 28 June 2017 that 80% of all infections were in Ukraine, with Germany second hardest hit with about 9%. On 28 June 2017, the Ukrainian government stated that the attack was halted. On 30 June 2017, the Associated Press reported experts agreed that Petya was masquerading as ransomware, while it was actually designed to cause maximum damage, with Ukraine being the main target.
content: A series of powerful cyberattacks using the Petya malware began on 27 June 2017 that swamped websites of Ukrainian organizations, including banks, ministries, newspapers and electricity firms. Similar infections were reported in France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Russia, United Kingdom, the United States and Australia. ESET estimated on 28 June 2017 that 80% of all infections were in Ukraine, with Germany second hardest hit with about 9%. On 28 June 2017, the Ukrainian government stated that the attack was halted. On 30 June 2017, the Associated Press reported experts agreed that Petya was masquerading as ransomware, while it was actually designed to cause maximum damage, with Ukraine being the main target.

title: Deloitte breach
contentText: September 2017: The Guardian reported that Deloitte suffered a cyberattack that breached the confidentiality of its clients and 244,000 staff, allowing the attackers to access "usernames, passwords, IP addresses, architectural diagrams for businesses and health information". Reportedly, Deloitte had stored the affected data in Microsoft's Azure cloud hosting service, without two-step verification. The attackers were thought to possibly have had access from as early as October 2016.
content: September 2017: Deloitte breach.
